title: Lawrence of Arabia (film)
text:
Lawrence of Arabia is a 1962 British <a href="Epic%20film">epic</a> <a href="historical%20drama">historical drama</a> film based on the life of <a href="T.%20E.%20Lawrence">T. E. Lawrence</a> and his 1926 book "<a href="Seven%20Pillars%20of%20Wisdom">Seven Pillars of Wisdom</a>". It was directed by <a href="David%20Lean">David Lean</a> and produced by <a href="Sam%20Spiegel">Sam Spiegel</a>, through his British company <a href="Horizon%20Pictures">Horizon Pictures</a>, and distributed by <a href="Columbia%20Pictures">Columbia Pictures</a>. The film stars <a href="Peter%20O%27Toole">Peter O'Toole</a> as Lawrence with <a href="Alec%20Guinness">Alec Guinness</a> playing <a href="Faisal%20I%20of%20Iraq">Prince Faisal</a>. The film also stars <a href="Jack%20Hawkins">Jack Hawkins</a>, <a href="Anthony%20Quinn">Anthony Quinn</a>, <a href="Omar%20Sharif">Omar Sharif</a>, <a href="Anthony%20Quayle">Anthony Quayle</a>, <a href="Claude%20Rains">Claude Rains</a>, and <a href="Arthur%20Kennedy">Arthur Kennedy</a>. The screenplay was written by <a href="Robert%20Bolt">Robert Bolt</a> and <a href="Michael%20Wilson%20%28writer%29">Michael Wilson</a>.
The film, a British production with American distribution, depicts Lawrence's experiences in the <a href="Ottoman%20Empire">Ottoman Empire</a>'s provinces of <a href="Hejaz%20Vilayet">Hejaz</a> and <a href="Syria%20%28region%29">Greater Syria</a> during <a href="World%20War%20I">World War I</a>, in particular his attacks on <a href="Aqaba">Aqaba</a> and <a href="Damascus">Damascus</a> and his involvement in the <a href="Arab%20National%20Council">Arab National Council</a>. Its themes include Lawrence's emotional struggles with the personal violence inherent in war, his own identity, and his divided allegiance between his native Britain with its army and his new-found comrades within the Arabian desert tribes.
"Lawrence of Arabia" was nominated for ten <a href="Academy%20Awards">Oscars</a> at the <a href="35th%20Academy%20Awards">35th Academy Awards</a> in 1963; it won seven, including <a href="Academy%20Award%20for%20Best%20Picture">Best Picture</a> and <a href="Academy%20Award%20for%20Best%20Director">Best Director</a>. It also won the <a href="Golden%20Globe%20Award%20for%20Best%20Motion%20Picture%20%E2%80%93%20Drama">Golden Globe Award for Best Motion Picture – Drama</a> and the <a href="British%20Academy%20Film%20Awards">BAFTA Awards</a> for <a href="BAFTA%20Award%20for%20Best%20Film">Best Film</a> and <a href="BAFTA%20Award%20for%20Outstanding%20British%20Film">Outstanding British Film</a>. The dramatic score by <a href="Maurice%20Jarre">Maurice Jarre</a> and the <a href="Super%20Panavision%2070">Super Panavision 70</a> cinematography by <a href="Freddie%20Young">Freddie Young</a> also won praise from critics.
The film is widely regarded as one of the <a href="List%20of%20films%20considered%20the%20best">greatest and most influential films ever made</a>. In 1991, it was deemed "culturally, historically, or aesthetically significant" by the United States <a href="Library%20of%20Congress">Library of Congress</a> and selected for preservation in the <a href="National%20Film%20Registry">National Film Registry</a>. In 1998, the <a href="American%20Film%20Institute">American Film Institute</a> placed it fifth on their <a href="AFI%27s%20100%20Years...100%20Movies">100 Years...100 Movies</a> list of the greatest American films, and it ranked seventh on their 2007 updated list. In 1999, the <a href="British%20Film%20Institute">British Film Institute</a> named the film the <a href="BFI%20Top%20100%20British%20films">third-greatest British film of all time</a>. In 2004, it was voted the <a href="List%20of%20films%20considered%20the%20best">best British film of all time</a> in a "<a href="Sunday%20Telegraph">Sunday Telegraph</a>" poll of Britain's leading filmmakers.
Plot.
The film is presented in two parts, divided by an <a href="Intermission%23Films">intermission</a>.
Part I.
The film opens in 1935, when Lawrence is killed in a motorcycle accident. At his memorial service at <a href="St%20Paul%27s%20Cathedral">St Paul's Cathedral</a>, a reporter tries, with little success, to gain insights into the remarkable, enigmatic man from those who knew him.
The story then moves back to the <a href="World%20War%20I">First World War</a>. Lawrence is a misfit <a href="British%20Army">British Army</a> <a href="lieutenant%20%28British%20Army%20and%20Royal%20Marines%29">lieutenant</a> who is notable for his insolence and education. Over the objections of <a href="Archibald%20Murray">General Murray</a>, Mr. Dryden of the <a href="Arab%20Bureau">Arab Bureau</a> sends him to assess the prospects of <a href="Faisal%20I%20of%20Iraq">Prince Faisal</a> in <a href="Arab%20Revolt">his revolt</a> against the <a href="Ottoman%20Empire">Turks</a>. On the journey, his <a href="Bedouin%20people">Bedouin</a> guide, Tafas, is killed by Sherif Ali for drinking from his well without permission. Lawrence later meets <a href="Harry%20Brighton">Colonel Brighton</a>, who orders him to keep quiet, make his assessment, and leave. Lawrence ignores Brighton's orders when he meets Faisal; his outspokenness piques the prince's interest.
Brighton advises Faisal to retreat after a major defeat, but Lawrence proposes a daring <a href="Battle%20of%20Aqaba">surprise attack on Aqaba</a>. Its capture would provide a port from which the British could offload much-needed supplies. The town is strongly fortified against a naval assault but only lightly defended on the landward side. He convinces Faisal to provide fifty men, led by a pessimistic Sherif Ali. The teenage orphans Daud and Farraj attach themselves to Lawrence as servants. They cross the <a href="Nefud%20Desert">Nefud Desert</a>, considered impassable even by the <a href="Bedouin">Bedouin</a>s, and travel day and night on the last stage to reach water. One of Ali's men, Gasim, succumbs to fatigue and falls off his camel unnoticed during the night. When Lawrence discovers him missing, he turns back and rescues Gasim, and Sherif Ali is won over. He gives Arab robes to Lawrence to wear.
Lawrence persuades <a href="Auda%20abu%20Tayi">Auda abu Tayi</a>, the leader of the powerful local <a href="Howeitat">Howeitat</a> tribe, to turn against the Turks. Lawrence's scheme is almost derailed when one of Ali's men kills one of Auda's because of a <a href="blood%20feud">blood feud</a>. Since retaliation by the Howeitat would shatter the fragile alliance, Lawrence declares that he will execute the murderer himself. Lawrence is then stunned to discover that the culprit is Gasim, the man for whom he risked his own life to save in the desert, but Lawrence shoots him anyway.
The next morning, the Arabs overrun the Turkish <a href="garrison">garrison</a>. Lawrence heads to <a href="Cairo">Cairo</a> to inform Dryden and the new commander, <a href="Edmund%20Allenby%2C%201st%20Viscount%20Allenby">General Allenby</a>, of his victory. While crossing the <a href="Sinai%20Desert">Sinai Desert</a>, Daud dies when he stumbles into <a href="dry%20quicksand">quicksand</a>. Lawrence is promoted to <a href="major%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">major</a> and given arms and money for the Arabs. He is deeply disturbed and confesses that he enjoyed executing Gasim, but Allenby brushes aside his qualms. Lawrence asks Allenby whether there is any basis for the Arabs' suspicions that the <a href="Sykes%E2%80%93Picot%20Agreement">British have designs on Arabia</a>. When pressed, Allenby states that there is none.
Part II.
Lawrence launches a <a href="guerrilla%20war">guerrilla war</a> by blowing up trains and harassing the Turks at every turn. An <a href="United%20States">American</a> <a href="war%20correspondent">war correspondent</a>, <a href="Jackson%20Bentley">Jackson Bentley</a>, publicises Lawrence's exploits and makes him famous. On one raid, Farraj is badly injured. Unwilling to leave him to be tortured by the enemy, Lawrence reluctantly shoots him dead and then flees.
When Lawrence scouts the enemy-held city of <a href="Daraa">Deraa</a> with Ali, he is taken, along with several Arab residents, to the Turkish <a href="Bey">Bey</a>. Lawrence is stripped, ogled, and prodded. Then, for striking out at the Bey, he is severely <a href="flogging">flogged</a> before he is thrown into the street, where Ali comes to his aid. The experience leaves Lawrence shaken. He returns to British headquarters in Cairo but does not fit in.
A short time later in <a href="Jerusalem">Jerusalem</a>, General Allenby urges him to support the <a href="Capture%20of%20Damascus">"big push" on Damascus</a>. Lawrence hesitates to return but finally relents.
Lawrence recruits an army that is motivated more by money than by the Arab cause. They sight a column of retreating Turkish soldiers, who have just <a href="Tafas%20massacre">massacred the residents of Tafas</a>. One of Lawrence's men is from <a href="Tafas">Tafas</a> and demands, "No prisoners!" When Lawrence hesitates, the man charges the Turks alone and is killed. Lawrence takes up the dead man's battle cry; the result is a slaughter in which Lawrence himself participates, despite Ali's protests. He regrets his actions thereafter.
Lawrence's men take Damascus ahead of Allenby's forces. The Arabs set up a council to administer the city, but the British cut off access to the <a href="public%20utility">public utilities</a>, leaving the desert tribesmen to debate how to maintain the occupation. Despite Lawrence's efforts, they bicker constantly, and soon abandon most of the city to the British.
Lawrence is promoted to <a href="colonel%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">colonel</a> and immediately ordered back to Britain, as his usefulness to both Faisal and the British is at an end. 
As he leaves the city, his automobile is passed by a motorcyclist, who leaves a trail of dust in his wake.
Cast.
The crew consisted of over 200 people, with the cast and extras included this number would increase to over 1000 people working to make the film.
Various members of the film's crew portrayed minor characters. First assistant director Roy Stevens played the truck driver who transports Lawrence and Farraj to the Cairo HQ at the end of Act I; the Sergeant who stops Lawrence and Farraj ("Where do you think you're going to, Mustapha?") is construction assistant Fred Bennett, and screenwriter <a href="Robert%20Bolt">Robert Bolt</a> has a wordless cameo as one of the officers watching Allenby and Lawrence confer in the courtyard (he is smoking a pipe). Steve Birtles, the film's <a href="Gaffer%20%28filmmaking%29">gaffer</a>, plays the motorcyclist at the Suez Canal; Lean himself is rumoured to be the voice shouting "Who are you?" Continuity supervisor Barbara Cole appears as one of the nurses in the Damascus hospital scene.
Historical accuracy.
Most of the film's characters are based on actual people to varying degrees. Some scenes were heavily fictionalised, such as the <a href="Battle%20of%20Aqaba">attack on Aqaba</a>, and those dealing with the Arab Council were inaccurate since the council remained more or less in power in <a href="Syria">Syria</a> until France deposed Faisal in 1920. Little background is provided on the history of the region, the First World War, and the Arab Revolt, probably because of Bolt's increased focus on Lawrence (Wilson's draft script had a broader, more politicised version of events). The second half of the film presents a fictional desertion of Lawrence's Arab army, almost to a man, as he moved farther north. The film's timeline is frequently questionable on the <a href="Arab%20Revolt">Arab Revolt</a> and <a href="World%20War%20I">World War I</a>, as well as the geography of the <a href="Hejaz">Hejaz</a> region. For instance, Bentley's meeting with Faisal is in late 1917, after the fall of Aqaba, and mentions that the United States has not yet entered the war, but the US had been in the war since April. Further, Lawrence's involvement in the Arab Revolt prior to the attack on Aqaba is completely excised, such as his involvement in the seizures of <a href="Yenbo">Yenbo</a> and <a href="Wejh">Wejh</a>. The rescue and the execution of Gasim are based on two separate incidents, which were conflated for dramatic reasons.
The film shows Lawrence representing the Allied cause in the Hejaz almost alone, with Colonel Brighton (<a href="Anthony%20Quayle">Anthony Quayle</a>) the only British officer there to assist him. In fact, there were numerous British officers such as colonels Cyril Wilson, Stewart Francis Newcombe, and Pierce C. Joyce, all of whom arrived before Lawrence began serving in Arabia. In addition, there was a French military mission led by Colonel Edouard Brémond serving in the Hejaz but it is not mentioned in the film. The film shows Lawrence as the sole originator of the attacks on the Hejaz railroad. The first attacks began in early January 1917 led by officers such as Newcombe. The first successful attack on the Hejaz railroad with a locomotive-destroying "Garland mine" was led by Major <a href="Herbert%20Garland">Herbert Garland</a> in February 1917, a month before Lawrence's first attack.
The film shows the <a href="Hashemite">Hashemite</a> forces as consisting of Bedouin guerrillas, but the core of the Hashemite forces was the regular Arab Army recruited from Ottoman Arab prisoners of war, who wore British-style uniforms with <a href="keffiyeh">keffiyeh</a>s and fought in conventional battles. The film makes no mention of the <a href="Sharifian%20Army">Sharifian Army</a> and leaves the viewer with the impression that the Hashemite forces were composed exclusively of Bedouin irregulars.
Representation of Lawrence.
Many complaints about the film's accuracy concern the characterisation of Lawrence. The perceived problems with the portrayal begin with the differences in his physical appearance; the <a href="Peter%20O%27Toole">Peter O'Toole</a> was almost taller than the Lawrence. His behaviour, however, has caused much more debate.
The screenwriters depict Lawrence as an egotist. It is not clear to what degree Lawrence sought or shunned attention, as evidenced by his use of various assumed names after the war. Even during the war, <a href="Lowell%20Thomas">Lowell Thomas</a> wrote in "With Lawrence in Arabia" that he could take pictures of him only by tricking him, but Lawrence later agreed to pose for several photos for Thomas's stage show. Thomas's famous comment that Lawrence "had a genius for backing into the limelight" can be taken to suggest that his extraordinary actions prevented him from being as private as he would have liked, or it can be taken to suggest that Lawrence made a pretence of avoiding the limelight but subtly placed himself at centre stage. Others point to Lawrence's own writings to support the argument that he was egotistical.
Lawrence's sexual orientation remains a controversial topic among historians. Bolt's primary source was ostensibly "Seven Pillars", but the film's portrayal seems informed by <a href="Richard%20Aldington">Richard Aldington</a>'s "Biographical Inquiry" (1955), which posited Lawrence as a "pathological liar and exhibitionist" as well as a homosexual. That is opposed to his portrayal in "Ross" as "physically and spiritually recluse". Historians such as <a href="Basil%20Liddell%20Hart">Basil Liddell Hart</a> disputed the film's depiction of Lawrence as an active participant in the attack and slaughter of the retreating Turkish columns who had committed the <a href="Tafas%20massacre">Tafas massacre</a>, but most current biographers accept the film's portrayal as reasonably accurate.
The film shows that Lawrence spoke and read Arabic, could quote the <a href="Quran">Quran</a>, and was reasonably knowledgeable about the region. It barely mentions his archaeological travels from 1911 to 1914 in Syria and Arabia and ignores his espionage work, including a prewar topographical survey of the Sinai Peninsula and his attempts to negotiate the release of British prisoners at <a href="Siege%20of%20Kut">Kut</a>, <a href="Mesopotamia">Mesopotamia</a>, in 1916. Furthermore, Lawrence is made aware of the <a href="Sykes%E2%80%93Picot%20Agreement">Sykes–Picot Agreement</a> very late in the story and is shown to be appalled by it, but he may well have known about it much earlier while he fought alongside the Arabs.
Lawrence's biographers have a mixed reaction towards the film. The authorised biographer Jeremy Wilson noted that the film has "undoubtedly influenced the perceptions of some subsequent biographers", such as the depiction of the film's Ali being real, rather than a composite character, and also the highlighting of the Deraa incident. The film's historical inaccuracies, in Wilson's view, are more troublesome than should be allowed under normal dramatic licence. At the time, Liddell Hart publicly criticised the film and engaged Bolt in a lengthy correspondence over its portrayal of Lawrence.
Representation of other characters.
The film portrays General Allenby as cynical and manipulative, with a superior attitude to Lawrence, but there is much evidence that Allenby and Lawrence liked and respected each other. Lawrence once said that Allenby was "an admiration of mine" and later that he was "physically large and confident and morally so great that the comprehension of our littleness came slow to him". The fictional Allenby's words at Lawrence's funeral in the film stand in contrast to the real Allenby's remarks upon Lawrence's death: "I have lost a good friend and a valued comrade. Lawrence was under my command, but, after acquainting him with my strategical plan, I gave him a free hand. His co-operation was marked by the utmost loyalty, and I never had anything but praise for his work, which, indeed, was invaluable throughout the campaign." Allenby also spoke highly of him numerous times and, much to Lawrence's delight, publicly endorsed the accuracy of "Seven Pillars of Wisdom". Although Allenby manipulated Lawrence during the war, their relationship lasted for years after its end, indicating that in real life, they were friendly, if not close. The Allenby family was particularly upset by the Damascus scenes in which Allenby coldly allows the town to fall into chaos as the Arab Council collapses.
Similarly, General Murray was initially sceptical of the Arab Revolt's potential but thought highly of Lawrence's abilities as an intelligence officer. Indeed, it was largely through Lawrence's persuasion that Murray came to support the revolt. The intense dislike shown toward Lawrence in the film is the opposite of Murray's real feelings, but Lawrence seemed not to hold Murray in any high regard.
The depiction of Auda abu Tayi as a man interested only in loot and money is also at odds with the historical record. Although Auda at first joined the revolt for monetary reasons, he quickly became a steadfast supporter of Arab independence, notably after Aqaba's capture. Despite repeated bribery attempts by the Turks, he happily pocketed their money but remained loyal to the revolt and went so far as to knock out his false teeth, which were Turkish-made. He was present with Lawrence from the beginning of the Aqaba expedition and in fact helped to plan it, along with Lawrence and Prince Faisal.
Faisal was far from being the middle-aged man depicted since he was in his early thirties at the time of the revolt. Faisal and Lawrence respected each other's capabilities and intelligence and worked well together.
The reactions of those who knew Lawrence and the other characters say much about the film's veracity. The most vehement critic of its accuracy was Professor <a href="A.%20W.%20Lawrence">A. W. (Arnold) Lawrence</a>, the protagonist's younger brother and literary executor, who had sold the rights to "Seven Pillars of Wisdom" to Spiegel for £25,000 and went on a campaign in the United States and Britain to denounce the film. He famously said, "I should not have recognised my own brother". In one pointed talk show appearance, he remarked that he had found the film "pretentious and false" and went on to say that his brother was "one of the nicest, kindest and most exhilarating people I've known. He often appeared cheerful when he was unhappy." Later, he said to the "<a href="New%20York%20Times">New York Times</a>", "[The film is] a psychological recipe. Take an ounce of narcissism, a pound of exhibitionism, a pint of sadism, a gallon of blood-lust and a sprinkle of other aberrations and stir well." Lowell Thomas was also critical of the portrayal of Lawrence and of most of the film's characters and believed that the train attack scenes were the only reasonably accurate aspect of the film.
Criticisms were not restricted to Lawrence. Allenby's family lodged a formal complaint against Columbia about his portrayal. Descendants of Auda abu Tayi and the real Sherif Ali, Sharif Nassir, went further by suing Columbia although the film's Ali was a fictional composite character. The Auda case went on for almost 10 years before it was dropped.
The film has its defenders. Biographer <a href="Michael%20Korda">Michael Korda</a>, the author of "Hero: The Life and Legend of Lawrence of Arabia", offers a different opinion. The film is neither "the full story of Lawrence's life or a completely accurate account of the two years he spent fighting with the Arabs." However, Korda argues that criticising its inaccuracy "misses the point." "The object was to produce, not a faithful docudrama that would educate the audience, but a hit picture." Stephen E. Tabachnick goes further than Korda by arguing that the film's portrayal of Lawrence is "appropriate and true to the text of "Seven Pillars of Wisdom"". A British historian of the Arab Revolt, David Murphy, wrote that although the film was flawed by various inaccuracies and omissions, "it was a truly epic movie and is rightly seen as a classic."
Production.
Pre-production.
Previous films about T. E. Lawrence had been planned but had not been made. In the 1940s, <a href="Alexander%20Korda">Alexander Korda</a> was interested in filming "The Seven Pillars of Wisdom" with <a href="Laurence%20Olivier">Laurence Olivier</a>, <a href="Leslie%20Howard%20%28actor%29">Leslie Howard</a>, or <a href="Robert%20Donat">Robert Donat</a> as Lawrence, but had to pull out owing to financial difficulties. David Lean had been approached to direct a 1952 version for the <a href="Rank%20Organisation">Rank Organisation</a>, but the project fell through. At the same time as pre-production of the film, <a href="Terence%20Rattigan">Terence Rattigan</a> was developing his play "<a href="Ross%20%28play%29">Ross</a>" which centred primarily on Lawrence's alleged <a href="homosexuality">homosexuality</a>. "Ross" had begun as a screenplay, but was re-written for the stage when the film project fell through. Sam Spiegel grew furious and attempted to have the play suppressed, which helped to gain publicity for the film. <a href="Dirk%20Bogarde">Dirk Bogarde</a> had accepted the role in "Ross"; he described the cancellation of the project as "my bitterest disappointment". Alec Guinness played the role on stage.
Lean and Sam Spiegel had worked together on "<a href="The%20Bridge%20on%20the%20River%20Kwai">The Bridge on the River Kwai</a>" and decided to collaborate again. For a time, Lean was interested in a biopic of <a href="Gandhi">Gandhi</a>, with Alec Guinness to play the title role and <a href="Emeric%20Pressburger">Emeric Pressburger</a> writing the screenplay. He eventually lost interest in the project, despite extensive pre-production work, including location scouting in India and a meeting with <a href="Jawaharlal%20Nehru">Jawaharlal Nehru</a>. Lean then returned his attention to T. E. Lawrence. <a href="Columbia%20Pictures">Columbia Pictures</a> had an interest in a Lawrence project dating back to the early '50s, and the project got underway when Spiegel convinced a reluctant <a href="A.%20W.%20Lawrence">A. W. Lawrence</a> to sell the rights to "<a href="The%20Seven%20Pillars%20of%20Wisdom">The Seven Pillars of Wisdom</a>" for £22,500.
<a href="Michael%20Wilson%20%28writer%29">Michael Wilson</a> wrote the original draft of the screenplay. Lean was dissatisfied with Wilson's work, primarily because his treatment focused on the historical and political aspects of the Arab Revolt. Lean hired <a href="Robert%20Bolt">Robert Bolt</a> to re-write the script to make it a character study of Lawrence. Many of the characters and scenes are Wilson's invention, but virtually all of the dialogue in the finished film was written by Bolt.
Lean reportedly watched <a href="John%20Ford">John Ford</a>'s film "<a href="The%20Searchers">The Searchers</a>" (1956) to help him develop ideas as to how to shoot the film. Several scenes directly recall Ford's film, most notably Ali's entrance at the well and the composition of many of the desert scenes and the dramatic exit from <a href="Wadi%20Rum">Wadi Rum</a>. Lean biographer <a href="Kevin%20Brownlow">Kevin Brownlow</a> notes a physical similarity between Wadi Rum and Ford's <a href="Monument%20Valley">Monument Valley</a>.
Filming.
The film was made by <a href="Horizon%20Pictures">Horizon Pictures</a> and distributed by <a href="Columbia%20Pictures">Columbia Pictures</a>. Principal photography began on 15 May 1961 and ended on 21 September 1962.
The desert scenes were shot in <a href="Jordan">Jordan</a> and <a href="Morocco">Morocco</a>, as well as <a href="Almer%C3%ADa%20%28province%29">Almería</a> and <a href="Do%C3%B1ana%20National%20Park">Doñana</a> in Spain. It was originally to be filmed entirely in Jordan; the government of <a href="Hussein%20of%20Jordan">King Hussein</a> was extremely helpful in providing logistical assistance, location scouting, transportation, and extras. Hussein himself visited the set several times during production and maintained cordial relationships with cast and crew. The only tension occurred when Jordanian officials learned that English actor <a href="Henry%20Oscar">Henry Oscar</a> did not speak Arabic but would be filmed reciting the <a href="Qur%27an">Qur'an</a>. Permission was granted only on condition that an imam be present to ensure that there were no misquotations.
Lean planned to film in Aqaba and the archaeological site at <a href="Petra">Petra</a>, which Lawrence had been fond of as a place of study. However, the production had to be moved to Spain due to cost and outbreaks of illness among the cast and crew before these scenes could be shot. The attack on Aqaba was reconstructed in a dried river bed in Playa del Algarrobico, southern Spain (at ); it consisted of more than 300 buildings and was meticulously based on the town's appearance in 1917. The execution of Gasim, the train attacks, and Deraa exteriors were filmed in the <a href="Almer%C3%ADa">Almería</a> region, with some of the filming being delayed because of a flash flood. The <a href="Sierra%20Nevada%20%28Spain%29">Sierra Nevada</a> mountains filled in for Azrak, Lawrence's winter quarters. The city of <a href="Seville">Seville</a> was used to represent <a href="Cairo">Cairo</a>, <a href="Jerusalem">Jerusalem</a>, and <a href="Damascus">Damascus</a>, with the appearance of <a href="Casa%20de%20Pilatos">Casa de Pilatos</a>, the <a href="Alc%C3%A1zar%20of%20Seville">Alcázar of Seville</a>, and the <a href="Plaza%20de%20Espa%C3%B1a%20%28Seville%29">Plaza de España</a>. All of the interiors were shot in Spain, including Lawrence's first meeting with Faisal and the scene in Auda's tent. The Tafas massacre was filmed in <a href="Ouarzazate">Ouarzazate</a>, Morocco, with Moroccan army troops substituting for the Turkish army; however, Lean could not film as much as he wanted because the soldiers were uncooperative and impatient.
The film's production was frequently delayed because shooting commenced without a finished script. Wilson quit early in the production, and playwright <a href="Beverley%20Cross">Beverley Cross</a> worked on the script in the interim before Bolt took over, although none of Cross's material made it to the final film. A further mishap occurred when Bolt was arrested for taking part in an anti-nuclear weapons demonstration, and Spiegel had to persuade him to sign a recognizance of good behaviour to be released from jail and continue working on the script.
O'Toole was not used to riding camels and found the saddle to be uncomfortable. During a break in filming, he bought a piece of foam rubber at a market and added it to his saddle. Many of the extras copied the idea and sheets of the foam can be seen on many of the horse and camel saddles. The Bedouin nicknamed O'Toole Ab al-'Isfanjah" (), meaning "Father of the Sponge". During the filming of the Aqaba scene, O'Toole was nearly killed when he fell from his camel, but it fortunately stood over him, preventing the horses of the extras from trampling him. Coincidentally, a very similar mishap befell the real Lawrence at the <a href="Battle%20of%20Aqaba">Battle of Abu El Lissal</a> in 1917.
Jordan banned the film for what was felt to be a disrespectful portrayal of Arab culture. Egypt, Omar Sharif's home country, was the only Arab nation to give the film a wide release, where it became a success through the endorsement of President <a href="Gamal%20Abdel%20Nasser">Gamal Abdel Nasser</a>, who appreciated the film's depiction of <a href="Pan-Arabism">Arab nationalism</a>.
<a href="Super%20Panavision%2070">Super Panavision</a> technology was used to shoot the film, meaning that spherical lenses were used instead of <a href="Anamorphic%20format">anamorphic</a> ones, and the image was exposed on a 65 mm negative, then printed onto a 70 mm positive to leave room for the soundtracks. Rapid cutting was more disturbing on the wide screen, so filmmakers had to apply longer and more fluid takes. Shooting such a wide ratio produced some unwanted effects during projection, such as a peculiar "flutter" effect, a blurring of certain parts of the image. To avoid the problem, the director often had to modify blocking, giving the actor a more diagonal movement, where the flutter was less likely to occur. David Lean was asked whether he could handle <a href="CinemaScope">CinemaScope</a>: "If one had an eye for composition, there would be no problem."
O'Toole did not share Lawrence's love of the desert and stated in an interview: "I loathe it."
Music.
The <a href="film%20score">film score</a> was composed by <a href="Maurice%20Jarre">Maurice Jarre</a>, little known at the time and selected only after both <a href="William%20Walton">William Walton</a> and <a href="Malcolm%20Arnold">Malcolm Arnold</a> had proved unavailable. Jarre was given just six weeks to compose two hours of orchestral music for "Lawrence". The score was performed by the <a href="London%20Philharmonic%20Orchestra">London Philharmonic Orchestra</a>. <a href="Adrian%20Boult">Sir Adrian Boult</a> is listed as the conductor of the score in the film's credits, but he could not conduct most of the score, due in part to his failure to adapt to the intricate timings of each cue, and Jarre replaced him as the conductor. The score went on to garner Jarre his first <a href="Academy%20Award">Academy Award</a> for Music Score—Substantially Original and is now considered one of the greatest scores of all time, ranking number three on the <a href="AFI%27s%20100%20Years%20of%20Film%20Scores">American Film Institute's top twenty-five film scores</a>.
Producer <a href="Sam%20Spiegel">Sam Spiegel</a> wanted to create a score with two themes to show the 'Eastern' and British side for the film. It was intended for Soviet composer <a href="Aram%20Khachaturian">Aram Khachaturian</a> to create one half and British composer <a href="Benjamin%20Britten">Benjamin Britten</a> to write the other.
The original soundtrack recording was originally released on <a href="Colpix%20Records">Colpix Records</a>, the records division of Columbia Pictures, in 1962. A remastered edition appeared on <a href="Castle%20Music">Castle Music</a>, a division of the <a href="Sanctuary%20Records">Sanctuary Records</a> Group, on 28 August 2006.
<a href="Kenneth%20J.%20Alford">Kenneth Alford</a>'s march "<a href="The%20Voice%20of%20the%20Guns">The Voice of the Guns</a>" (1917) is prominently featured on the soundtrack. One of Alford's other pieces, the "<a href="Colonel%20Bogey%20March">Colonel Bogey March</a>", was the musical theme for Lean's previous film "<a href="The%20Bridge%20on%20the%20River%20Kwai">The Bridge on the River Kwai</a>".
A complete recording of the score was not heard until 2010 when Tadlow Music produced a CD of the music, with Nic Raine conducting the <a href="City%20of%20Prague%20Philharmonic">City of Prague Philharmonic</a> from scores reconstructed by <a href="Leigh%20Phillips">Leigh Phillips</a>.
Release.
Theatrical run.
The film premiered at the <a href="Odeon%20Leicester%20Square">Odeon Leicester Square</a> in London on 10 December 1962 (Royal Premiere) and was released in the United States on 16 December 1962.
The original release ran for about 222 minutes (plus overture, intermission, and exit music). A post-premiere memo (13 December 1962) noted that the film was of 70 mm film, or of 35 mm film. With of 35 mm film projected every minute, this corresponds to exactly 222.11 minutes. Richard May, VP Film Preservation at Warner Bros., sent an email to Robert Morris, co-author of a book on "Lawrence of Arabia", in which he noted that "Gone With the Wind" was never edited after its premiere and is of 35 mm film (without leaders, overture, intermission, entr'acte, or walkout music), corresponding to 220.93 min. Thus, "Lawrence of Arabia" is slightly more than 1 minute longer than "Gone With the Wind" and is, therefore, the longest movie ever to win a Best Picture Oscar.
In January 1963, "Lawrence" was released in a version edited by 20 minutes; when it was re-released in 1971, an even shorter cut of 187 minutes was presented. The first round of cuts was made at the direction and even insistence of David Lean, to assuage criticisms of the film's length and increase the number of showings per day; however, during the 1989 restoration, he passed blame for the cuts onto deceased producer Sam Spiegel. In addition, a 1966 print was used for initial television and video releases which accidentally altered a few scenes by reversing the image.
The film was screened out of competition at the <a href="1989%20Cannes%20Film%20Festival">1989 Cannes Film Festival</a> and at the 2012 <a href="Karlovy%20Vary%20International%20Film%20Festival">Karlovy Vary International Film Festival</a>.
"Lawrence of Arabia" was re-released theatrically in 2002 to celebrate the film's fortieth anniversary.
Restored director's cut.
A restored version was undertaken by <a href="Robert%20A.%20Harris">Robert A. Harris</a> and Jim Painten under the supervision of director David Lean. It was released in 1989 with a 216-minute length (plus overture, intermission, and exit music).
Most of the cut scenes were dialogue sequences, particularly those involving General Allenby and his staff. Two whole scenes were completely excised—Brighton's briefing of Allenby in Jerusalem before the Deraa scene and the British staff meeting in the field tent—and the Allenby-briefing scene has still not been entirely restored. Much of the missing dialogue involves Lawrence's writing of poetry and verse, alluded to by Allenby in particular, saying "the last poetry general we had was <a href="Arthur%20Wellesley%2C%201st%20Duke%20of%20Wellington">Wellington</a>". The opening of Act II existed in only fragmented form, where Faisal is interviewed by Bentley, as well as the later scene in Jerusalem where Allenby convinces Lawrence not to resign. Both scenes were restored to the 1989 re-release. Some of the more graphic shots of the Tafas massacre scene were also restored, such as the lengthy panning shot of the corpses in Tafas, and Lawrence shooting a surrendering Turkish soldier.
Most of the still-missing footage is of minimal import, supplementing existing scenes. One scene is an extended version of the Deraa torture sequence, which makes Lawrence's punishment more overt in that scene. Other scripted scenes exist, including a conversation between Auda and Lawrence immediately after the fall of <a href="Aqaba">Aqaba</a>, a brief scene of Turkish officers noting the extent of Lawrence's campaign, and the battle of <a href="Petra">Petra</a> (later reworked into the first train attack), but these scenes were probably not filmed. The actors still living at the time of the re-release dubbed their own dialogue, though <a href="Jack%20Hawkins">Jack Hawkins</a>'s dialogue had to be dubbed by <a href="Charles%20Gray%20%28actor%29">Charles Gray</a>, who had already provided Hawkins' voice for several films after Hawkins developed throat cancer in the late 1960s. A full list of cuts can be found at the <a href="Internet%20Movie%20Database">Internet Movie Database</a>. Reasons for the cuts of various scenes can be found in Lean's notes to Sam Spiegel, Robert Bolt, and <a href="Anne%20V.%20Coates">Anne V. Coates</a>. The film runs 227 minutes in the most recent <a href="director%27s%20cut">director's cut</a> available on Blu-ray Disc and DVD.
Television and home media.
On the evenings of 28 and 29 January 1973, ABC broadcast the film over two evenings, due to the film's length. On 21 August 1977, ABC re-broadcast it, in one 8 p.m. to midnight showing.
"Lawrence of Arabia" has been released in five different DVD editions, including an initial release as a two-disc set (2001), followed by a shorter single disc edition (2002), a high resolution version of the director's cut with restored scenes (2003) issued as part of the <a href="Superbit">Superbit</a> series, as part of the Columbia Best Pictures collection (2008), and in a fully restored special edition of the director's cut (2008).
<a href="Martin%20Scorsese">Martin Scorsese</a> and <a href="Steven%20Spielberg">Steven Spielberg</a> helped restore a version of the film for a DVD release in 2000.
New restoration, Blu-ray, and theatrical re-release.
An <a href="8K%20resolution">8K</a> scan/<a href="4K%20resolution">4K</a> intermediate <a href="digital%20restoration">digital restoration</a> was made for <a href="Blu-ray">Blu-ray</a> and theatrical re-release during 2012 by <a href="Sony%20Pictures%20Entertainment">Sony Pictures</a> to celebrate the film's 50th anniversary. The Blu-ray edition of the film was released in the United Kingdom on 10 September 2012 and in the United States on 13 November 2012. The film received a one-day theatrical release on 4 October 2012 and a two-day release in Canada on 11 and 15 November 2012, and it was re-released in the United Kingdom on 23 November 2012.
According to Grover Crisp, executive VP of restoration at Sony Pictures, the new 8K scan has such high resolution that it showed a series of fine concentric lines in a pattern "reminiscent of a fingerprint" near the top of the frame. This was caused by the film emulsion melting and cracking in the desert heat during production. Sony had to hire a third party to minimise or eliminate the rippling artefacts in the new restored version. The digital restoration was done by Sony Colorworks DI, <a href="Prasad%20Studios">Prasad Studios</a>, and MTI Film.
A 4K digitally restored version of the film was screened at the <a href="2012%20Cannes%20Film%20Festival">2012 Cannes Film Festival</a>, at the 2012 <a href="Karlovy%20Vary%20International%20Film%20Festival">Karlovy Vary International Film Festival</a>, at the V Janela Internacional de Cinema in <a href="Recife">Recife</a>, Brazil, and at the 2013 <a href="Cinequest%20Film%20%26amp%3B%20Creativity%20Festival">Cinequest Film & Creativity Festival</a> in <a href="San%20Jose%2C%20California">San Jose, California</a>.
Reception.
Upon its release, "Lawrence of Arabia" was a huge critical and financial success and it remains popular among viewers and critics alike. The film's visuals, score, screenplay and performance by <a href="Peter%20O%27Toole">Peter O'Toole</a> have all been common points of acclaim; the film as a whole is widely considered a masterpiece of world cinema and one of the <a href="List%20of%20films%20considered%20the%20best">greatest films ever made</a>. Additionally, its visual style has influenced many directors, including <a href="George%20Lucas">George Lucas</a>, <a href="Sam%20Peckinpah">Sam Peckinpah</a>, <a href="Stanley%20Kubrick">Stanley Kubrick</a>, <a href="Martin%20Scorsese">Martin Scorsese</a>, <a href="Ridley%20Scott">Ridley Scott</a>, <a href="Brian%20De%20Palma">Brian De Palma</a>, <a href="Oliver%20Stone">Oliver Stone</a>, and <a href="Steven%20Spielberg">Steven Spielberg</a>, who called the film a "miracle".
The <a href="American%20Film%20Institute">American Film Institute</a> ranked "Lawrence of Arabia" 5th in its original and 7th in its updated <a href="AFI%27s%20100%20Years...100%20Movies%20%2810th%20Anniversary%20Edition%29">100 Years...100 Movies</a> lists and first in its list of the greatest American films of the <a href="Epic%20film">"epic" genre</a>. In 1991, the film was deemed "culturally, historically, or aesthetically significant" by the <a href="Library%20of%20Congress">Library of Congress</a> and selected for preservation in the United States <a href="National%20Film%20Registry">National Film Registry</a>. In 1999, the film placed third in the <a href="BFI%20Top%20100%20British%20films">British Film Institute's poll</a> of the best British films of the 20th century, and in 2001 the magazine "<a href="Total%20Film">Total Film</a>" called it "as shockingly beautiful and hugely intelligent as any film ever made" and "faultless". It was ranked in the top ten films of all time in the 2002 "<a href="Sight%20%26amp%3B%20Sound">Sight & Sound</a>" directors' poll. In 2004, it was voted the best British film of all time by over 200 respondents in a "<a href="Sunday%20Telegraph">Sunday Telegraph</a>" poll of Britain's leading filmmakers. Additionally, O'Toole's performance is often considered one of the greatest in all of cinema, topping lists from both "<a href="Entertainment%20Weekly">Entertainment Weekly</a>" and "<a href="Premiere%20Magazine">Premiere</a>". T. E. Lawrence, portrayed by O'Toole, was selected as the <a href="AFI%27s%20100%20Years...%20100%20Heroes%20and%20Villains">tenth-greatest hero in cinema history</a> by the <a href="American%20Film%20Institute">American Film Institute</a>.
In addition, "Lawrence of Arabia" is currently one of the highest-rated films on <a href="Metacritic">Metacritic</a>; it holds a perfect 100/100 rating, indicating "universal acclaim", based on seven reviews. It has a 93% "Certified fresh" approval rating on <a href="Rotten%20Tomatoes">Rotten Tomatoes</a> based on 121 reviews with an average rating of 9.3/10 from critics with the consensus stating, "The epic of all epics, "Lawrence of Arabia" cements director David Lean's status in the filmmaking pantheon with nearly four hours of grand scope, brilliant performances, and beautiful cinematography."
Some critics—notably <a href="Bosley%20Crowther">Bosley Crowther</a> and <a href="Andrew%20Sarris">Andrew Sarris</a>—have criticised the film for its incomplete and inaccurate portrayal of Lawrence.
Legacy.
Film director <a href="Steven%20Spielberg">Steven Spielberg</a> considers this his favourite film of all time and the one that inspired him to become a filmmaker. "Lawrence of Arabia" also inspired numerous other <a href="Adventure%20film">adventure</a>, <a href="science%20fiction">science fiction</a> and <a href="fantasy">fantasy</a> stories in modern popular culture, including <a href="Frank%20Herbert">Frank Herbert</a>'s "<a href="Dune%20%28franchise%29">Dune</a>" franchise, <a href="George%20Lucas">George Lucas</a>'s "<a href="Star%20Wars">Star Wars</a>" franchise, <a href="Ridley%20Scott">Ridley Scott</a>'s "<a href="Prometheus%20%282012%20film%29">Prometheus</a>" (2012), <a href="George%20Miller%20%28director%29">George Miller</a>'s "" (2015), and <a href="Walt%20Disney%20Animation%20Studios">Disney</a>'s "<a href="Frozen%20%28franchise%29">Frozen</a>" franchise.
In 1991, "Lawrence of Arabia" was deemed "culturally, historically, or aesthetically significant" and selected for preservation in the United States <a href="Library%20of%20Congress">Library of Congress</a> <a href="National%20Film%20Registry">National Film Registry</a>. In 2012, the <a href="Motion%20Picture%20Editors%20Guild">Motion Picture Editors Guild</a> listed the film as the seventh best-edited film of all time based on a survey of its membership.
Later film.
In 1990, the made-for-television film "" was aired. It depicts events in the lives of Lawrence and Faisal subsequent to "Lawrence of Arabia" and featured <a href="Ralph%20Fiennes">Ralph Fiennes</a> as Lawrence and <a href="Alexander%20Siddig">Alexander Siddig</a> as Prince Faisal.
